titlestmt.titleproper: J. Walter Thompson Company. Bill Sharfman papers
Guide to the J. Walter Thompson Company. Bill Sharfman papers, 1958-2010 and undated RL.11325
titlestmt.author: Ashton Merck

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-13 18:20:26 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: J. Walter Thompson Company. Bill Sharfman papers
did.abstract: Founded in 1864, the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT) is one of the oldest and largest enduring advertising agencies in the United States. It is headquartered in New York. Bill Sharfman was an executive who worked in strategic planning for JWT USA in New York as well as for the JWT subsidiary Brouillard Communications before opening his own agency, Sharfman & Co. The J. Walter Thompson Company Bill Sharfman papers include correspondence, speeches, research and policy reports and other printed materials, as well as audiovisual materials (video- and audio cassettes). Companies represented include Brouillard Communications, Chevron (Standard Oil of California), Ernst & Young (PACE Awards), GM, Goodyear, Harvard Business School, Kodak, Olivetti, Renault, Rockefeller Center, St. Ivel (Dairy Crest), Tayto (Golden Wonder), Televisión Nacional de Chile, and McNeil (Tylenol). Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into the following series: General Files; Brouillard Communications; J. Walter Thompson; Sharfman & Co.; Speeches; Academic Career; Print Materials; Automotive Industry; Audiovisual Materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Founded in 1864, the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT) is one of the oldest and largest enduring advertising agencies in the United States. It is headquartered in New York. William L. (Bill) Sharfman was an executive who worked in strategic planning for JWT USA in New York as well as for the JWT subsidiary Brouillard Communications before opening the Sharfman & Co. agency.

William L. Sharfman was born in 1942. Sharfman graduated from the University of Michigan (BA, 1964) and Columbia University (MA, 1965; PhD, 1969). Sharfman taught at Columbia (Preceptor and Lecturer, 1966-1970) and Idaho State University (Dept. of English, 1970-1972). Sharfman worked at Time Sharing Information Services (President, 1972-1973); Metragraphic Systems (Vice-President, 1973-1976); J. Walter Thompson (Research and Planning, 1976-1978; Senior Vice-President, Strategic Planning, 1982-1985) and Brouillard Communications (Planning Director, 1978-1982). Sharfman opened the Sharfman & Co. agency in 1985.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access note. Collection contains audiovisual/photographic formats that may need to be reformatted before use. Contact Research Services for access.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The J. Walter Thompson Company. Bill Sharfman papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2016-2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], J. Walter Thompson Company. Bill Sharfman papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2016-0275, 2016-0305, 2017-0009, 2017-0046

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials may be found in the following Hartman Center collections: J. Walter Thompson Company Account Files; J. Walter Thompson Company Information Center records; J. Walter Thompson Company London Office records; Thomas Garbett papers.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The J. Walter Thompson Company Bill Sharfman papers include correspondence, speeches, research and policy reports and other printed materials, as well as audiovisual materials (video- and audio cassettes). Companies represented include Brouillard Communications, Chevron (Standard Oil of California), Ernst & Young (PACE Awards), GM, Goodyear, Harvard Business School, Kodak, Olivetti, Renault, Rockefeller Center, St. Ivel (Dairy Crest), Tayto (Golden Wonder), Televisión Nacional de Chile, and McNeil (Tylenol). Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Highlights of the General Files include: materials related to the School of Jazz/Music Inn in Lenox, MA in the late 1950s; an interview with Dr. W. Edwards Deming; and a White House Summit on Innovation in 1999.

scopecontent.p: Clippings included with letters sent to Sharfman from JWT and other ad agencies congratulating him on his promotion in 1982

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from before, during, after Sharfman's work in advertising. Bulk of correspondence relates to a promotion at JWT in 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records from Sharfman's time at the School of Jazz in Lenox MA, as well as information about the documentary, Music Inn. Jazz musicians such as Ornette Coleman, Max Roach, Bill Evans, Don Cherry, and Jimmy Giuffre, among others, are mentioned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of Preface and Acknowledgments from Lee Sage, Winning the Innovation Race.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Academic series includes materials from Sharfman's career as an English professor, includingsuch as bibliographies, exams, assignments, lecture notes, and teaching evaluations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recommendation letters by Sharfman on behalf of other people

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sharfman's notes and syllabi for various courses in English at Idaho State and Columbia College; most undated. Course subjects include the city in modern literature, art and literature in the 19th century, and the novel. Explanatory note from Sharfman about his teaching method included in folder 1.

scopecontent.p: Brandweek, 2001

"Some Remarks on Management in the Eleventh Hour," ADE Bulletin, Feb. 1977

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bulletin also includes a feature on the state of the academic job market for English PhDs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various issues of Automobile magazine which include articles and interviews by Sharfman. Interviewees include Morley Safer (of 60 Minutes), Betsy Ancker-Johnson, Heinz Prechter, Steve Earle, Jerry Curry, and Emilio Anchisi. Articles include review of the Baedeker, and "Escape from Tokyo."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Automotive series documents the early years of the Ernst & Young/Automotive News PACE Awards for Innovation, for which Sharfman served as a judge for several years. The series also includes several presentations related to automotive innovation in the 1990s. The bulk of Sharfman's automobile reviews and related writing can be found in the Print Materials series.
